Ragefresh: Just type it anyway, and if it doesn't take, change permission in the sudoers file to include yourself. To do that you have to to 'apple shift G' in the finder then '/etc/' in the box. in the etc folder you will find the sudoers file, get info on it and + yourself in the permissions. if your user password is nothing than it won't take either. Good luck

Anyone try this to disable Adobe from checking for updates? 


Machine-wide disablement
To disable access to updates for all users on a given machine, administrators can create an admin preference file. (This file disables access to updates both from the Help > Updates menu, as well as automatic update checks.) Create a plain-text file named AdobeUpdaterAdminPrefs.dat with the following contents:







	1



Put the file in the following location:

Mac OS	/Library/Application Support/Adobe/AAMUpdaterInventory/1.0/AdobeUpdaterAdminPrefs.dat 
Windows XP and Higher	 C:\Program files\common files\adobe\AAMUpdaterInventory\1.0\AdobeUpdaterAdminPrefs.dat 
Windows XP and higher (64-bit)	 C:\Program files(x86)\common files\adobe\AAMUpdaterInventory\1.0\AdobeUpdaterAdminPrefs.dat 
Note: This will also prevent administrators from checking for updates and installing updates through that update check. This is easily dealt with by simply renaming the AdobeUpdaterAdminPrefs.dat file, running the update check and installation with the Adobe Application Manager, then restoring the file to it's original name.

Alternatively, with the system wide update disablement in place, administrators can install updates by downloading them from http://www.adobe.com/downloads/updates.

FOR ANY AND ALL LION USERS ON MAC!!!!!!!!

AS FAR AS PASTING THE INFO INTO TERMINAL, DON"T DO IT!!!!!!!
OPEN FINDER THEN GO TO THE TOP TOOLBAR OR WHATEVER AND CLICK GO
THEN SELECT GO TO FOLDER
ENTER /private
ONCE DONE GO TO FILE etc
THEN LOOK FOR THE FILE THAT JUST SAYS hosts
THEN ENTER THE STUFF IN BETWEEN THE APPROPRIATE NUMBERS.
IF  YOU HAVE SOME PASSWORD LOCK YOU MAY NEED TO AUTHENTICATE IT!!!
ONCE DONE RESTART YOUR MAC AND IT WILL WORK FINE!!!!!!!!!!!!! :) HOORAY!

What exactly is our password for the terminal? also i am signed in as admin. Is it the password for the admin account?

To open the hosts file in Mac OS Lion, open the Terminal Application and type:

sudo nano /private/etc/hosts

hit enter

type your password (if prompted)

hit enter

do Step 5 in INSTRCTiONS.rtf

for Step 6: When youâre done, press control-o to save the file. You will see a prompt at the bottom of the screen that reads:

File Name to Write: /private/etc/hosts

Hit Enter to save the file in this location then press control-x to exit the nano text editor.

Once the hosts file has been edited, you need to flush the DNS cache for the changes to take affect. To do this, run the following command:

$ dscacheutil -flushcache

continue with step 7 in INSTRCTiONS.rtf
